About this course
Biomedical Science is a highly exciting, fast paced discipline that will give you a deep understanding of the relationship between humans and the maintenance of their health. Todayâs biomedical scientists work in cutting-edge clinical environments, performing sophisticated medical work that benefits patientsâ health immeasurably. The role of a biomedical scientist is one of challenge, responsibility and reward.

The programme is based upon the application of cutting-edge biological sciences to the solution of contemporary medical and medically related problems. This programme has a strong medical and research emphasis and is aimed at producing the next generation of professional biomedical scientists. A unique feature of the BMS programme at Abertay is the extensive training in laboratory-based skills and techniques we provide in all four years of your studies. The focused curriculum plus the academic research associated with your final year Honours project will equip you to offer strong relevant skills to prospective employers. For those taking the Integrated route (see below), the bursary-supported clinical placement provides a unique training and educational experience in the setting of a cutting-edge modern hospital laboratory.

The programme has two routes: a Standard route; and an Integrated route:

How you learn
A wide variety of teaching methods are used. You will typically receive around 20 hours of lectures, tutorials and practicals per week, and spend a comparable amount of time on personal study and preparing for assessments.

How you are assessed
Assessment is carried out via a combination of coursework assignments, practical reports, class tests and examinations. Additionally, you will be assessed on a number of professional âcompetenciesâ throughout the programme.

column4:
Core Themes

What you study
Common Foundation Pathway
(All students study these subjects)
Stage 1: Biological and related scientific principles associated with health, disease and medicine.
Stage 2: Greater depth of biology underpinning health, disease and medicine. Laboratory skills training continues.

Standard Route
Stage 3: Advanced understanding of the biological basis of health, disease and medicine, in combination with advanced techniques and skills training. Professional studies form a significant part of Year 3.
Stage 4: Biology of health, disease and medicine. You will complete a substantive research project.

Integrated Route
Stage 3: In addition to advanced biology of health, disease and medicine, Year 3 is characterised by [a] professional studies and [b] the clinical work placement.
Stage 4: Biology of health, disease and medicine. You will also complete a research project.

column3:
Specialist Facilities:

A range of well equipped, modern laboratories are available for use by Biomedical Science students. In addition to this, the Scottish Informatics Mathematics Biology & Statistics (SIMBIOS) research facility at Abertay provides students with access to top class researchers working in the exciting field of biology and computing.

column4:
Career Opportunities:

Approximately 60% of graduates from our BMS programmes have entered the NHS as Biomedical Scientists. When HPC Registered, i.e. after 12-24 months for students from the Standard BMS route, or immediately upon starting work for graduates from the Integrated route, as a NHS biomedical scientist you would expect a starting salary of Â£19,166*. After 2-3 years experience and on gaining your Specialist Skills Diploma, and subject to successful promotion to Specialist Biomedical Scientist, you would expect to enter band 6 salary which rises in 9 annual increments to Â£31,004. Ultimate earnings, for those in a specialised Consultant's post, may reach Â£88,397*. Moreover, the NHS is a secure employer and offers good additional benefits such as pensions and holidays.

*Salary rates derived from the NHS publication Pay and Conditions for NHS Staff covered by the Agenda for Change agreement (2006), and represent the latest information available at the time of writing.

For those not entering the NHS as Biomedical Scientists, the BMS Honours degree is also relevant to other related career areas including scientific or technical laboratory work outwith the NHS (e.g. in private industry or universities). Many past graduates who have chosen non-NHS careers have obtained employment in private medical or science laboratories. Several have opted for other biology careers such as school teaching (biology), or further study (MSc or PhD). For those whose career aspirations shift away from science, the generic skills and âgraduatenessâ gained during study on the programme are likely to be useful in many alternative sectors, for example management, retail, leisure and care work.

MatureIn order to determine an applicant's ability to benefit from study or research at the University of Abertay Dundee, a range of standard and flexible criteria will be used in considering applications.



In most circumstances applications will be considered in light of the following:



Applications from mature students are assessed on the same criteria used for school leavers e.g. SQA Highers or GCE A Levels, where relevant school leaving qualifications exist. For those without standard entry qualifications, consideration is given to experience gained as well as professional qualifications and other forms of learning that could provide evidence of ability to benefit from a particular course.



The successful completion of approved access courses (such as those offered by Dundee College in association with the universities of Abertay, Dundee and St Andrews) provides significant evidence of ability to benefit from study at Abertay.



For further advice please use our Got a Question section.

OverseasThe University makes offers of entry to courses based on qualifications offered worldwide. For undergraduate level entry, if you are studying the International Baccalaureate, you would be expected to achieve at least 26 points. We consider a variety of alternative qualifications on an individual basis. Examples of the qualifications accepted for entry from Overseas students in recent years include: Chinese High School Diploma, Malaysia Advanced Certificate of Education (STPM), European Baccalaureate, West African Senior Secondary School Certificate (WASSCE) with a minimum of 5 passes at B3 or better from external examination plus an accceptable level of pass in JAMB, Indian Secondary Certificate plus Indian Higher Secondary Certificate (10+2), Pakistan Secondary Certificate plus Pakistan Higher Secondary Certificate, Hong Kong Advanced Level Certificate (HKALE).

All applicants are required to provide certified proof of competence in English Language. The University's minimum requirements are IELTS 6.0 (with no band lower than 5.0), TOEFL CBT 223, TOEFL 563, TOEFL IBT 85 or a suitable equivalent qualification.

column4:
Professional accreditation

The programme is fully Accredited by the Institute of Biomedical Science (IBMS) and fully Approved by the Health Professions Council (HPC). Accreditation/Approval means that graduates from the Standard route will be eligible to seek employment in the NHS as Trainee Biomedical Scientists, and that graduates from the Integrated route will be able to eligible to seek employment in the NHS as State Registered Biomedical Scientists.

It is important to note that graduates who wish to follow a career as NHS Biomedical Scientists (without undertaking subsequent and extensive postgraduate education) must undertake a Biomedical Sciences degree that has been professionally Accredited and Approved, such as that offered at Abertay University.

While studying on this course you will gain a number of practical skills which are useful in any field of business such as how to use email, type reports, build a database and use the internet effectively, as well as being introduced to specialised software relevant to your subject choices. You will also learn how to sift through vast quantities of detailed information quickly and to present the important points in a concise and straightforward manner. As you progress through the degree course you will gain other incidental skills which will prove invaluable in any future working environment. These may include:
1. Learning how to learn effectively
2. Self-motivation
3. Assertiveness
4. Time management
5. Meeting deadlines
6. Problem solving
7. Analysis, synthesis, discrimination and judgement
8. Logical and reasoned thinking.

column4:
Teamwork

Being able to work as a member of a team is an important quality in a University student. Working in a team situation allows you to utilise your own personal strengths and to build upon areas where you are lacking by learning from other people. It also allows you to gain experience in leading discussions and delegating responsibility, as well as learning to become an effective listener â an important leadership quality which can sometimes be overlooked. Making a positive contribution to a joint project enables you to develop team-working skills.
Working together on coursework often allows you to form close friendships in your social life as you learn to listen to and trust other peopleâs judgements.
